story.text: Jan 2 The New York Times reported the following stories on its business pages on Tuesday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy. * Wal-Mart Stores Inc. (WMT.N) is determined to push energy-saving light bulbs with the help of some unlikely partners. * U.S. regulators are growing concerned about banks that lease office space to hedge funds in hopes of gaining big clients. * While sites like YouTube and Myspace crack down on nudity and violence, new sites are treading into the realm of unfiltered live broadcasts. * As 2006 ended, the opinion of stock market investors could not have been clearer: there are blue skies ahead. * After a better-than-average year in the stock market, and a much weaker one in housing, homeowners and investors in the U.S. appear neither exuberant nor glum about 2007. * The new year is being approached with worries that a slowdown in housing could hurt the overall U.S. economy. * Business groups have started using "speed networking," a corporate equivalent of speed dating, to explore business prospects. ((Compiled by Aditi Samajpati; Bangalore Equities Newsdesk +91 80 4135 5800; within U.S. +1 646 223 8780))
story.title: press digest - new york times business - jan 2
